content:
Every letter, claim, writ, summons and process shall be notified or forwarded unanswered to Us immediately on receipt. Notice shall also be given to Us immediately after You or any person claiming to be indemnified shall have knowledge of any impending prosecution, inquest, inquiry or offer of composition in connection with any such accident and/or occurrence.

This condition in its entirety is a condition precedent to liability and failure to comply with any of the above requirements in respect of any accident and/or occurrence will result in You or Your Authorised Driver being denied indemnity under both Section I and Section II of the Policy in respect of that particular accident and/or occurrence.

Notwithstanding the No Claim Discount provisions set out herein, failure to comply with this condition precedent will additionally result in You losing all or part of Your No Claim Discount as set out in NCD Table 3 under No Claim Discount (NCD) Section.
questions: How does the requirement to immediately notify and forward every letter, claim, writ, summons, and process affect indemnity under both Section I and Section II of the policy in the event of an accident or occurrence?

What are the consequences on indemnity and No Claim Discount if You or Your Authorised Driver fail to notify the insurer immediately upon knowledge of any impending prosecution, inquest, inquiry, or offer of composition related to an accident?
In what ways does the condition precedent regarding notification of legal documents and impending legal actions interact with the No Claim Discount provisions, specifically referencing NCD Table 3?
How does the policy define the timing and manner of notice to the insurer for claims arising from an accident or occurrence to maintain coverage under Sections I and II?
What is the impact on indemnity if a claimant responds to a letter, claim, writ, summons, or process before notifying the insurer as required by the policy?
How does the policy treat indemnity if the insured or any person claiming indemnity becomes aware of an impending inquiry or offer of composition but delays notification to the insurer?
What specific types of legal notifications related to an accident or occurrence must be forwarded unanswered to the insurer, and how does this affect coverage?
How does the condition precedent affect claims involving multiple parties, such as the insured and an authorised driver, in terms of notification and indemnity?
What are the implications for indemnity and No Claim Discount if notification requirements are met for some but not all legal documents received in connection with an accident?
How does the policy handle situations where the insured receives knowledge of an impending prosecution after the claim has already been submitted but fails to notify the insurer immediately?
In cases where the insured fails to comply with the notification condition precedent, how is the loss of No Claim Discount determined according to NCD Table 3?
How does the policy ensure that failure to notify the insurer immediately does not result in partial indemnity under either Section I or Section II for the same accident or occurrence?
What is the role of the insured’s knowledge versus the knowledge of any person claiming indemnity in triggering the notification requirement and its effect on coverage?
How does the policy address the forwarding of legal documents that are received after the claim has been settled or closed?
What is the relationship between the notification condition precedent and the insurer’s right to deny indemnity for a particular accident or occurrence?
How does the policy define ‘immediately’ in the context of notifying the insurer about legal documents and impending legal actions, and what are the consequences of delays?
How does the notification condition precedent interact with other general exclusions or conditions in the policy that might affect indemnity for an accident or occurrence?
What documentation or proof might the insurer require to verify that the insured complied with the immediate notification condition precedent?
How does the policy treat indemnity if the insured complies with the notification requirement for an accident but fails to notify for a subsequent related inquiry or offer of composition?
In what ways does the notification condition precedent protect the insurer’s interests in managing claims under both Section I and Section II of the policy?
